about_me.copy:
I have 15+ years of experience in web design and development and I enjoy putting my creative, mechanical and organizational skills to use both professionally and personally.  My career has given me a range of experience across online marketing, educational multimedia, and e-commerce projects. The constant evolution of computing and connectivity requires continuous learning and application of new technology and skills.

I enjoy collaborating with marketers, designers and developers and working on projects where I can develop and streamline code using the latest technologies and concepts. I have extensive experience in the core web technologies: Javascript, HTML5 and CSS3. I have also worked with: Amazon AWS, GITHUB, Apache Velocity, CVS, Node.js and npm, Angular.js, Express.js, EJS, mySQL, Photoshop, Illustrator, Sketch, Video Editing and the Apple and Android Pay API’s. I also understand SEO optimization, A/B testing, ad tracking and digital acquisition marketing.

On a personal side, I have enjoyed building and designing from an early age- from model trains and aircraft to model rocketry and large scale radio-controlled aircraft. More recently I put all these construction and design skills to use building and contracting our homes. I enjoyed the hands-on process from architectural planning, framing, electrical circuits, plumbing, tile work and carpentry all the way through to finishing. My other passion is aviation and I acquired my private pilot’s license in 2008.

In 2014, my family relocated to the Raleigh-Durham area and I have enjoyed working remotely for Time Inc. and trading my weekday 2.5 hour roundtrip commute for more time with my family.

about_site.copy:
My portfolio was created to showcase my most recent projects as well as a means of describing my personality and wide array of interests. A design goal was to create a clean, easy to use site that could be used to demonstrate my current skills while pushing me to explore and implement new techniques and technologies.

Site development began with creative research. This consisted of gathering ideas and developing a general style to follow. Wireframes and site flow were sketched using paper and pencil. Site requirements were compiled and analyzed. After this I began researching some of the newer web technologies and chose AWS and Node.js to serve my portfolio.

The layout was designed in Sketch using the hand drawn wireframes as a starting point. This stage included color and font selection as well as creation of the logo. The creative process also included mobile first followed by desktop versions which were viewed on actual devices to ensure a quality user interface and design.

Once the site was designed and finalized in Sketch I installed Node.js on my AWS LightSail server instance. This was followed by the installation of express.js as my web framework software and EJS as the templating language. These technologies would serve my HTML pulling data from a JSON file, which will be upgraded to a database at some point. DOM manipulation is handled by JavaScript. CSS media queries render the proper layouts for both mobile and desktop, mobile being first priority.

After studying code examples and reviewing online classes I began to develop my web app. Pages were coded (HTML), stylized (CSS) and JavaScript functions were created to handle visual effects. Testing and review was done using both Safari and Chrome and their respective inspectors. Testing on Android devices was accomplished via the Android device emulator. PC browsers were accesses via Mac OSX running Windows on Parallels. While debugging and fine tuning the functionality, user experience, layout and design I continuously committed changes via command line to Git Hub. On the server instance I would then pull the latest committed files to the live server.

Other features of this project include:

  • Images optimized.
  • Resources, including images served via Amazon’s Cloudfront CDN.
  • Web app running on lightsail server instance which has the ability to perform a complete instance backup.
  • Registered with Google Web Tools for statistics.
  • Node.js and Express.js enable scalability, including the future use of a database.
  • All server and client side technologies used, current and future, are JavaScript based.
  • Coded cleanly using HTML5.
  • CSS written locally as .scss and preprocessed via Sass.
  • UI via CSS media queries.
  • Motion and visual elements are handled via CSS for simple fast rendering within browser.
  • Image use is solely for figures and galleries, all other graphical elements are created via CSS.
  • Designed mobile first, with an interest in keeping the code and files light.

A general breakdown of technologies used are as follows:

  • HTML5 for the page structure along with CSS3 for the layout. This includes use of media queries, viewport width and height values and most importantly flexbox layout.
  • JavaScript handles visual effects, such as image overlay, image parallax and header banner image features. I’ve incorporated some of the new ECMAScript 6 features such as constants and block-scoped variables, as well as template literals and arrow functions.
  • Node.JS and NPM as the backbone of my site, pushing it into web app territory. Using node as my second tier I integrated web app structure into my portfolio site. At the moment using a JSON data file but in the future I plan on adding a database as the third tier.
  • Along with Node.js, there are additional packages installed on my server instance such as Express.js, EJS, and nodemailer. Express.js is the web app framework for Node.js, which supports the development of my web application. EJS is the templating language that generates my HTML using plain JavaScript.
  • AWS has been utilized for hosting my site on a server instance running node.js. Node.js, package installation via npm and repository access is managed via Command Line Interface.
  • I’ve also used AWS CloudFront for content delivery of my site resources.
  • Along with these newer technologies, I’ve continued to use Photoshop and Sketch to handle the creative portion of my portfolio. Photoshop is used to crop, resize and adjust images. These are optimized for minimum size, maximum quality. Sketch is the OSX application I used to create the design for the site, both mobile and desktop. Once the design was finalized to about 90% HTML/CSS coding began.

portfolio_projects.title: People Shop Ecommerce Site
portfolio_projects.description:
Time Inc. management decided to test the People brand potential to generate revenue from an e-commerce storefront. Products that were being sold related to the people theme and current celebrity trends. These products included accessories, jewelry, housewares and beauty products.

Tasks taken to complete this project are listed below:

  • In order to meet the hard go live date I broke down the most basic needs of the project and tackled them accordingly.
  • The primary task was to integrate all requested features of the site and confirm proper operation when served to all browsers.
  • The core of my efforts included the integration of HTML, CSS and JavaScript libraries into our e-commerce platform using the velocity templating language. A large portion of time spent was scripting functionality of the product option and quantity selectors.
  • Content was optimized, including images, scripts and styles. Resources were served using Amazon cloudfront CDN.
  • I utilized our backend team and offshore developers to complete and test various components of the storefront.

My efforts concluded when People Shop hit the target go live date fully tested and full featured. Marketing was extremely happy with the project from start to finish. Our performance and demonstration of progress along the way via screen share kept them informed, satisfied and minimized stress.

I utilized my logic and reason to manage time and energy, making sure that the most critical components were completed and tested ahead of schedule. Other skills demonstrated were, leadership, adaptability, self awareness. Technical skills put to use were HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Velocity, jQuery, Flexible/Mobile Design, UX/UI and Photoshop.

portfolio_projects.title: Apple Pay
portfolio_projects.description:
Upper management requested our group develop a way to include the new Apple Pay for Web on our magazine subscription order forms. Using an iOS device or Safari desktop browser coupled with fingerprint verification Apple Pay seamlessly processes the financial transaction and then sends the validated order to our fulfillment system. This would enable users to subscribe to our products quickly, thus improving the conversion rate.

General action items for this project are listed below:

  • I was tasked with displaying the Apple Pay button and hiding current form elements should user have Apple Pay available.
  • It was necessary to develop the proper JavaScript, HTML and CSS for proper UI, UX and data handling.
  • We also had to validate form data as per our fulfillment requirements.
  • This was followed by passing this proper valid data between the Apple Pay API and our servers for fulfillment.
  • I worked closely with our backend and fulfillment teams while researching the Apple Pay API thus enabling me to successfully integrate Apple Pay on our forms on schedule.
  • At completion I had to simplify this code and create reusable library.

We met our target go live date and I created documentation for the rest of our team on Apple Pay usage within our order forms. I co-developed our Apple Pay library for quick drop in on new and live order forms saving development time by nearly 90%.

We successfully met our target go live date. I created documentation for the rest of our team on Apple Pay usage within our order forms. I also co-developed our Apple Pay library for quick drop in on new and live order forms saving development time by nearly 90%.

During this project I demonstrated self awareness, focus, tenacity, eagerness to learn a new technology and project management skills. My technical knowledge utilizes was the following; JavaScript, HTML/CSS, Velocity and the poorly documented at the time ApplePay API.

portfolio_projects.title: Time Shop
portfolio_projects.description:
Similar to our other online store fronts we developed the Time Shop as a way to leverage the brand identity to sell products previously for sale on various disjointed platforms. This would also give them an avenue of marketing to sell other items marketing was testing for potential value. We’d feature items that were new ideas and add items that were topical in nature for sales and promotions. It also allowed these physical products to be easily linked to from other promotional elements.

Our in house design group completed the layout and consulted with me as far as user interaction and viability according to our current backend technology. I built out the site using HTML, CSS and JavaScript along with Apache Velocity for the templating. I finished it up by testing cross browser and cross mobile device. This was then QA’d and debugged from feedback received from our offshore QA team as well as our e-commerce fulfillment department.

portfolio_projects.title: Image Gallery Parallax Effect
portfolio_projects.description:
My goal was to create an image gallery scroll for this portfolio with an interesting visual parallax effect on the images.

The steps I took to complete this gallery are listed below:

  • Using paper cutouts I determined what values a script would need to calculate the image position in relation to its parent's scroll location within the gallery container. This assisted me with developing the math and determining the reference points for animation on user scroll.
  • After this was roughed out I created a simple and reusable CSS and HTML structure for the test page.
  • I then began to develop the script gathering values and calculating element positions and locations referencing my rough-out listed above.
  • Once a functioning prototype was complete I shifted my efforts toward consolidating the HTML, CSS and Javascript for use as a library item. This condensed the logic and code by about 50%.

This resulted in a site enhancement which I developed from scratch that also serves to demonstrate skill and creativity. The feature animates quickly, works on both mobile and desktop and on either the X or Y axis.

This project utilized my knowledge of HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Photoshop and creative UI enhancement.

portfolio_projects.title: Banner Ad JavaScript Library
portfolio_projects.description:
I tasked myself with the development of a single JavaScript file that would enable developers to quickly deploy new banner AD creative to our ad serving system. This was for use on all brands across Time Inc. We had been facing major problems with display issues, inconsistent and inefficient development times, and messy duplication of code.

Below is a general outline of the tasks taken during development:

  • To begin I combined updated original functions from current examples and developed new code that would expose touts on the parent page from within an iframe. This would also have the same results if served without use of an iFrame.
  • I then re-evaluated all functions and streamlined into a singe JavaScript object.
  • Testing on existing ads that had bug as well as on new creatives was the final step.

My efforts enabled our offshore team to cut new ad script development time by 80%. The library enabled quick updates across the board and was easy for new developers to pickup and utilize successfully.

Skills employed were JavaScript, Tracking, Cross Browser testing. I also trained resources on the use of this library.

portfolio_projects.title: Android Pay
portfolio_projects.description:
Following the successful deployment of Apple Pay on our order forms the company shifted focus to Android. I was tasked with developing a way to utilize Android Pay on our templated and non templated subscription order forms. This would enable users to subscribe to our products using an android device and Android Pay payment method. A secondary task was to enable Google Optimize and have this technology deploy Android Pay dynamically for testing variations.

Task list:

  • Step one, learn the Android Pay API quickly and begin to implement the elements on a test form, this gave us a visual starting point.
  • Next I used the Android Pay API to request user data for form field population.
  • I then worked with back-end team to integrate transaction connections (Chase Paymentech.)
  • This was followed by testing fulfillment for successfully placed valid test orders.
  • I then converted and streamlined all code into a reusable library for all order forms.

The result was a library that was utilized to deploy Android Pay to all of our templated and non-templated order forms, as well as through Google Optimize. Marketing saw a 1-2% order increase on forms tested. The library also enabled quick development of forms requiring this feature.

Skills: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Velocity, Android Pay API. Collaboration and project management.

portfolio_projects.title: Google Maps Autofill
portfolio_projects.description:
People Magazine marketing decided to test the Google Maps user address autofill on their subscription order forms. The goal was to create a less demanding user checkout and track this increase in conversions.

  • I began by researching the Google Maps autofill API and created a simple form to test my understanding of its features and functionality.
  • Using JavaScript I wrote up code and created an include file.
  • This include file was tested on multiple order forms on various browsers and devices by our team followed by our offshore team.

I finished the development on time handing over a simple and effective script. This module could be dropped into all our forms without any modifications to either script or form HTML. Using Google Optimize the marketing department was able to split test the autofill feature which I created quickly and on their own, saving time and costs.

Skills utilized: HTML, CSS, JavaScript. Project Management and training of resources.

portfolio_projects.title: Solutions outside of scope
portfolio_projects.description:
I found a budget friendly in house solution to our digital media shortage. I discussed a solution with my co-worker that involved filming, editing and exporting all video and auto for this digital test.

  • I found a budget friendly in house solution to our digital media shortage. I discussed a solution with my co-worker that involved filming, editing and exporting all video and auto for this digital test.
  • We introduced this solution to the project manager, she then gathered the author and other team members who were willing to read questions, answers and visually demonstrate concepts on camera.
  • Our first physical step was to record video and audio clips, digitized and split them up using video editing software.
  • Next these clips were then exported to the proper web ready file type and size using the current video and audio compression tools.

Our efforts enabled the project manager to have complete digital testing support media to complement the text book with a massive savings over having it done out of house.

The following skills were necessary for this task: Video and Audio editing. Self confidence. Problem solving. I applied extra effort when it wasn’t necessary for the scope of my job.
